head.supplied: 14/5/90 ¶ ¶ My Assistant had made out a list of such plants from your Flora, ¶ ¶ ¶ dear Prof Tate, as did not occur at all or under other designations in the Census. ¶ I send it to you with some ...

div.p: Barr Smith Library, University of Adelaide, SA.

My Assistant had made out a list of such plants from your Flora,
Tate (1890).
dear Prof Tate, as did not occur at all or under other designations in the Census.
B89.12.03. Editors' notes to the enclosure, below, identify the names completely missing or that appear under other names. I send it to you with some notes, and have entered in msc. the actual omissions, some of which seem to have occurred by typographic shortcomings. I should like to have specimens (even only fragments) of the following, so as to have them represented in the herb. here from S.A.
Each of the names in the following list, except '— Clarkei', has been crossed through, presumably by Tate. The only species in the list collected in SA before 1890 in MEL are Eremophila clarkei and Kochia pentatropis . It is not known what crossing through a name here and in the enclosure signifies.
I may have been the cause of some phytogeographic errors through former writings of my own.
I suppose, you will publish every year some additions and emendations in the form of your Flora, so as to be glued in

p.style: font-family: Geneva; font-size: 12pt; margin-left: 1.75in; margin-right: 0in; text-indent: 0in;
font-family: Geneva; font-size: 12pt; margin-left: 1.75in; margin-right: 0in; text-indent: 0in;

div.p:
Prof. Tates Flora not entered in Census as S.A.
While filed separately, the list that follows is considered to be the enclosure mentioned in the letter, since the species listed are included in Tate (1890) but are not shown as present in SA in the second edition of M's Systematic Census (B89.12.03). The list has been annotated by M; his comments are on the right-hand side of the page. Many names in the list have been crossed through, as shown, presumably by Tate.
The two works were going through the press at the same time. The printing of Tate (1890) was proceeding so fast that M wrote that 'the Census of 1889 will not be timely for you' and sent Tate a spare copy of the available proof-sheets and notified him of some SA species that were not included in pages already printed (M to R. Tate, 5 October 1889). In M to R. Tate, 12 October 1889, M explained that he had not included all species newly claimed for a colony as 'I had not yet leisure enough to examine all the new species or the plants from new localities carefully'. See also M to R. Tate, 15 October 1889, and notes to M to R. Tate, November 1889 (in this edition as 89-11-00h), for further explanations of plants excluded from M's Second census.

p.seg: The typic broadleaved form occurs only on the coast of N.SW in shady forests Yours is the form G. pendula

p.style: font-family: Geneva; margin-left: 0.3335in; margin-right: 0in; text-indent: -0.3335in; font-size: 9pt;

note.p: In B62.02.03, p. 108, M had placed G. pendula in synonymy with G. parviflora, which is listed from SA in B89.12.03, p. 21.

note.p: Ptilotus schwartzii, absent from B89.12.03, was included in Tate (1890) with the name attributed to M, as it was in Tate (1889a), p. 82. It is evidently based upon P. Fraseri var Schwartzii, described by M in B88.06.01, p. 163, where M wrote 'these characteristics seem sufficient for raising this supposed variety to specific rank'.

cell.style: padding-left: 0.075in; padding-right: 0.075in; padding-top: 0in; padding-bottom: 0in; border: none;
padding-left: 0.075in; padding-right: 0.075in; padding-top: 0in; padding-bottom: 0in; border: none;
padding-left: 0.075in; padding-right: 0.075in; padding-top: 0in; padding-bottom: 0in; border: none;

p.seg: Aotus villosa could never have been found in the interior by Sturt; it may reach the Glenelg-River.

p.style: font-family: Geneva; margin-left: 0.3335in; margin-right: 0in; text-indent: -0.3335in; font-size: 9pt;

note.p: The species was listed in Tate (1890), p. 221, as being found in his region G, 'the volcanic area of the south-east corner of the Province or the Mount Gambier district' (p. 204). Part of the Glenelg River lies in the far south-east of SA but it is mostly in Vic. M is evidently commenting on the assertion in Bentham (1863-78), vol. 2, p. 91, that a specimen was collected by Sturt in SA.

note.p: H. multistriata is given in Tate (1890), p. 84, but not in the systematic list, p. 228. In the 'Additions and corrections', p. 302, the error is corrected: 'For Hakea multistriata, read multilineata'. H. multilineata is in B89.12.03, p. 121. H. multistriata is listed again below.

p.seg: I know only one Crinum from the Murray-R., namely C. flaccidum; I know from culture C. pedunculatum of the east-coast, but that occurs nowhere in SA,

p.style: font-family: Geneva; margin-left: 0.3335in; margin-right: 0in; text-indent: -0.3335in; font-size: 9pt;

note.p: Tate (1890), p. 258, lists C. pedunculatum as found in his region M, the plain of the lower Murray.

p.seg: it may be that a second species exists towards Capricorn, and that may be C. angustifolium, which is not identical with C. Asiaticum

p.seg: = L. exaltatum, oldest name in the genus Leaves never kidney-shaped

p.style: font-family: Geneva; margin-left: 0.3335in; margin-right: 0in; text-indent: -0.3335in; font-size: 9pt;

note.p: Tate (1890), p. 143, recombined RBr's Villarsia reniformis without comment. M's view of its position varied; see APNI entries (accessed 6 April 2023) for a guide to his treatments.

cell.style: padding-left: 0.075in; padding-right: 0.075in; padding-top: 0in; padding-bottom: 0in; border: none;
padding-left: 0.075in; padding-right: 0.075in; padding-top: 0in; padding-bottom: 0in; border: none;
cell.p: M. montanum grows never in mountains; it belongs to the desert-region; hence I adopted the name M. Dampierii Cunn

padding-left: 0.075in; padding-right: 0.075in; padding-top: 0in; padding-bottom: 0in; border: none;

p.style: font-family: Geneva; margin-left: 0.3335in; margin-right: 0in; text-indent: -0.3335in; font-size: 9pt;

note.p: The entry in B89.12.03, p. 175, is for the orthographic variant (not the name under which he described it used by Tate) E. behrii, which is shown as found only in SA.

cell.style: padding-left: 0.075in; padding-right: 0.075in; padding-top: 0in; padding-bottom: 0in; border: none;
padding-left: 0.075in; padding-right: 0.075in; padding-top: 0in; padding-bottom: 0in; border: none;
padding-left: 0.075in; padding-right: 0.075in; padding-top: 0in; padding-bottom: 0in; border: none;

p.style: font-family: Geneva; margin-left: 0.3335in; margin-right: 0in; text-indent: -0.3335in; font-size: 9pt;

note.p: Not in B89.12.03; it is included in Tate (1890), p. 256, attributed to R. Brown. Brown (1810), p. 314, described T. pauciflora and Tate's entry may be a typesetter's error not detected in proof. Brown also described another orchid species Microtis parviflora (p. 321), but this genus is quite unlike Thelymitra. There is no entry for T. pauciflora in B89.12.03, pp. 188-9.

note.p: Not in B89.12.03. Tate (1890),,p. 256, attributes the name to Fitzgerald; for M's views on Fitzgerald's species see, for example, M to W..Thiselton-Dyer, 25 July 1885.

p.seg: These I will critically study when I get leisure, in time for the next Census.

p.style: font-family: Geneva; font-size: 9pt; margin-left: 0.3335in; margin-right: 0.2752in; text-indent: -0.3335in;

note.p: M has bracketed the Thelymitra and Caladenia entries.

cell.p: I prefer the name D. longifolia

cell.style: padding-left: 0.075in; padding-right: 0.075in; padding-top: 0in; padding-bottom: 0in; border: none;
padding-left: 0.075in; padding-right: 0.075in; padding-top: 0in; padding-bottom: 0in; border: none;

p.style: font-family: Geneva; margin-left: 0.3335in; margin-right: 0in; text-indent: -0.3335in; font-size: 9pt;

note.p: No publication of P. laevis has been found (APNI, accessed 6 April 2023). Perhaps a clerical error repeating the epithet of the previous entry? P. tenuicaulis and P. ochreatus are listed in Tate (1890), p. 261, but are not in Mueller's Census.

cell.style: padding-left: 0.075in; padding-right: 0.075in; padding-top: 0in; padding-bottom: 0in; border: none;
padding-left: 0.075in; padding-right: 0.075in; padding-top: 0in; padding-bottom: 0in; border: none;

padding-left: 0.075in; padding-right: 0.075in; padding-top: 0in; padding-bottom: 0in; border: none;

p.seg: Probably not distinct from the common P. obtusifolius of Europe, which I identified already 1848 with the Austral plant.

p.style: font-family: Geneva; margin-left: 0.3335in; margin-right: 0in; text-indent: -0.3335in; font-size: 9pt;

note.p: P. obtusifolius is listed for SA in B89.12.03, p. 204.

cell.style: padding-left: 0.075in; padding-right: 0.075in; padding-top: 0in; padding-bottom: 0in; border: none;
padding-left: 0.075in; padding-right: 0.075in; padding-top: 0in; padding-bottom: 0in; border: none;

p.seg: Never yet found south of Tasmania

p.style: font-family: Geneva; margin-left: 0.3335in; margin-right: 0in; text-indent: -0.3335in; font-size: 9pt;

note.p: C. antarctica not in B89.12.03. M used the name C. zosterifolia from at least the time of publication of his first Census (B83.03.04), and it is shown from SA under that name in B89.12.03. For his rationale for the name change, see M to. J. Agardh, 1 January 1883.

cell.style: padding-left: 0.075in; padding-right: 0.075in; padding-top: 0in; padding-bottom: 0in; border: none;

p.style: font-family: Geneva; margin-left: 0.3335in; margin-right: 0in; text-indent: -0.3335in; font-size: 9pt;

note.p: S. discifer? S. discifer not in B89.12.03; it was described in Tate (1889c), p. 131.

cell.style: padding-left: 0.075in; padding-right: 0.075in; padding-top: 0in; padding-bottom: 0in; border: none;

note.p: S. muelleri not in B89.12.03; it had been described in Tate (1885), p. 70. See also R. Tate to M, 6 May 1884.

cell.style: padding-left: 0.075in; padding-right: 0.075in; padding-top: 0in; padding-bottom: 0in; border: none;
padding-left: 0.075in; padding-right: 0.075in; padding-top: 0in; padding-bottom: 0in; border: none;

note.p: In B89.12.03, p. 223, M synonymized Dichelachne under Stipa; neither this nor the next species is listed. They were listed, however, under Dichelachne in the first edition of the Census (B86.03.04, p. 133).

cell.style: padding-left: 0.075in; padding-right: 0.075in; padding-top: 0in; padding-bottom: 0in; border: none;

note.p: Listed for SA in B89.12.03, p. 227, under its earlier name E. setifolia.

cell.style: padding-left: 0.075in; padding-right: 0.075in; padding-top: 0in; padding-bottom: 0in; border: none;

p.seg: H. densiflora is an older and far apter name; several other species are far more sericeous.

p.style: font-family: Geneva; margin-left: 0.3335in; margin-right: 0in; text-indent: -0.3335in; font-size: 9pt;

note.p: Listed for SA in B89.12.03, p. 1, under H. desiflora.

cell.style: padding-left: 0.075in; padding-right: 0.075in; padding-top: 0in; padding-bottom: 0in; border: none;

note.p: This?

p.seg: is C. parviflora L., which may be only a var. of C. hirsuta

p.style: font-family: Geneva; margin-left: 0.3335in; margin-right: 0in; text-indent: -0.3335in; font-size: 9pt;

note.p: C. hirsuta listed for SA in B89.12.03, p. 9.

cell.style: padding-left: 0.075in; padding-right: 0.075in; padding-top: 0in; padding-bottom: 0in; border: none;

p.style: font-family: Geneva; margin-left: 0.3335in; margin-right: 0in; text-indent: -0.3335in; font-size: 9pt;

note.p: E. lasiocarpum is not in B89.12.03 although M had used the name in B79.06.04, p. 34, for Blennodia lasiocarpum, citing B55.09.03, p. 100; however, it was not described there but merely cited as his MS name. He described it in B62.03.03, p. 40, where he cited as a synonym his E. blennoides in B53.04.01, p. 367. M split Blennodia species, some listed under Sisymbrium, others under Erysimum. In B89.12.03, p. 9; he lists for SA his original 1853 name.

cell.style: padding-left: 0.075in; padding-right: 0.075in; padding-top: 0in; padding-bottom: 0in; border: none;

p.seg: Did I ever receive this plant?

p.style: font-family: Geneva; margin-left: 0.3335in; margin-right: 0in; text-indent: -0.3335in; font-size: 9pt;
p.seg: Not in B89.12.03; described in Tate (1885), p. 67; a specimen (MEL 767) was sent to M with R. Tate to M, 11 September 1883.

cell.style: padding-left: 0.075in; padding-right: 0.075in; padding-top: 0in; padding-bottom: 0in; border: none;
padding-left: 0.075in; padding-right: 0.075in; padding-top: 0in; padding-bottom: 0in; border: none;

p.seg: I believe var of C. linearis

p.style: font-family: Geneva; margin-left: 0.3335in; margin-right: 0in; text-indent: -0.3335in; font-size: 9pt;

note.p: Listed for SA in B89.12.03, p. 12, under C. linearis.

cell.style: padding-left: 0.075in; padding-right: 0.075in; padding-top: 0in; padding-bottom: 0in; border: none;

p.style: font-family: Geneva; margin-left: 0.3335in; margin-right: 0in; text-indent: -0.3335in; font-size: 9pt;

note.p: Not in B89.12.03; there is a brief description in Tate (1890), p. 24, but in the systematic list, p. 209, it is given as E. brachyphyllus, attributed to M. E. microphyllus is listed for SA in B89.12.03, p. 19; in his description (B55.09.03, p. 100), M states that the species is found on the 'low coast ranges of Spencer's and St. Vincent's Gulf', compatible with the distribution given for E. brachyphyllus given by Tate. APNI (accessed 7 April 2023) gives both E. brachyphyllus and E. microphyllus as synonyms of Leionema microphyllum.

p.style: font-family: Geneva; margin-left: 0.3335in; margin-right: 0in; text-indent: -0.3335in; font-size: 9pt;

note.p: Not in B89.12.03. The species had been described in Tate (1886), p. 71, under the joint authority of M and Tate. The description states that 'this plant simulates in a remarkable manner D. plantaginella'; B89.12.03, p. 50, includes D. plantaginella for SA.

p.seg: = P. polyota I never saw the plant prostrate

p.style: font-family: Geneva; margin-left: 0.3335in; margin-right: 0in; text-indent: -0.3335in; font-size: 9pt;

note.p: Listed for SA in B89.12.03, p. 64, under P. polyota.

p.style: font-family: Geneva; margin-left: 0.3335in; margin-right: 0in; text-indent: -0.3335in; font-size: 9pt;

note.p: M has written Templetonia Battii, Eucla. at the top of the page. M described it in B87.02.01, from a specimen collected near Eucla. Tate (1890), p. 65, made without explanation a new combination, creating Bossiaea batii, giving Tate as the authority in the species list, p. 222. T. battii is listed for SA in B89.12.03, p. 65.

cell.style: padding-left: 0.075in; padding-right: 0.075in; padding-top: 0in; padding-bottom: 0in; border: none;

p.style: font-family: Geneva; margin-left: 0.3335in; margin-right: 0in; text-indent: -0.3335in; font-size: 9pt;

note.p: var in M's hand.

cell.style: padding-left: 0.075in; padding-right: 0.075in; padding-top: 0in; padding-bottom: 0in; border: none;

p.style: font-family: Geneva; margin-left: 0.3335in; margin-right: 0in; text-indent: -0.3335in; font-size: 9pt;

note.p: Tate (1890) p. 69, lists both L. australis and a variety Behrianus, but does not include the variety in the species list, p. 224. Listed for SA in B89.12.03, p. 66 under L. australis.

cell.style: padding-left: 0.075in; padding-right: 0.075in; padding-top: 0in; padding-bottom: 0in; border: none;
padding-left: 0.075in; padding-right: 0.075in; padding-top: 0in; padding-bottom: 0in; border: none;

p.style: font-family: Geneva; margin-left: 0.3335in; margin-right: 0in; text-indent: -0.3335in; font-size: 9pt;

note.p: H. multistriata is given in Tate (1890), p. 84, but not in the systematic list, p. 228. In the 'Additions and corrections', p. 302, the error is corrected: 'For Hakea multistriata, read multilineata.' H. multilineata is in B89.12.03, p. 121.

cell.style: padding-left: 0.075in; padding-right: 0.075in; padding-top: 0in; padding-bottom: 0in; border: none;
padding-left: 0.075in; padding-right: 0.075in; padding-top: 0in; padding-bottom: 0in; border: none;

p.seg: An unfortunate mixture of two plants, must be obliterated

p.style: font-family: Geneva; margin-left: 0.3335in; margin-right: 0in; text-indent: -0.3335in; font-size: 9pt;

note.p: J. Black (1952), p. 531, in a list of changes required for parts I and II of his Flora, wrote 'Delete Trianthema humillima , F. v. M. Mr. J. H. Willis, of the Melbourne Herbarium, informs me that further investigation of specimens from Maitland, Yorke Peninsula, prove that this is not a flowering plant, but a small moss, Gigaspermum repens (Hook.) Lindb. Mueller mistook the columella of the spore-case (sporocarp, sporangium) for the erect free-central placenta of Trianthema and the numerous spores for seeds'. See also M to O. Tepper, 30 June 1886 (in this edition as 86-06-30a), and M to R. Tate, 15 October 1889, in which he requested that this false 'species' should be omitted.

cell.style: padding-left: 0.075in; padding-right: 0.075in; padding-top: 0in; padding-bottom: 0in; border: none;

p.style: font-family: Geneva; margin-left: 0.3335in; margin-right: 0in; text-indent: -0.3335in; font-size: 9pt;

note.p: In his Eucalyptographia, third Decade (B79.13.11) under E. obliqua, M discussed De Candolle's E. cneorifolia, among other things pointing out that it has been 'confused with one of low arid country in Kangaroo-Island, which belongs to E. oleosa'. Tate (1890), p. 232, lists the species as from Kangaroo Island and Port Lincoln district. E cneorifolia is not included in B89.12.03 but E. oleosa is listed for SA, p. 99.

cell.style: padding-left: 0.075in; padding-right: 0.075in; padding-top: 0in; padding-bottom: 0in; border: none;
padding-left: 0.075in; padding-right: 0.075in; padding-top: 0in; padding-bottom: 0in; border: none;

p.style: font-family: Geneva; margin-left: 0.3335in; margin-right: 0in; text-indent: -0.3335in; font-size: 9pt;

note.p: Not in B89.12.03; it was described in Tate (1889c), p. 129.

cell.style: padding-left: 0.075in; padding-right: 0.075in; padding-top: 0in; padding-bottom: 0in; border: none;
padding-left: 0.075in; padding-right: 0.075in; padding-top: 0in; padding-bottom: 0in; border: none;
padding-left: 0.075in; padding-right: 0.075in; padding-top: 0in; padding-bottom: 0in; border: none;

p.seg: DC. According to Clarke our M. variifol is to be reduced to the Asiatic species of DC. I have not yet verified this.

note.p: M has bracketed the two Minura entries. Neither species is listed in B89.12.03 but in B76.04.03, p.56, M included both species under M. candollei, the name which is listed for SA in B89.12.03, p. 131.

p.seg: We have similar aberrations in Polygonum Spiraea &c

p.style: font-family: Geneva; margin-left: 0.3335in; margin-right: 0in; text-indent: -0.3335in; font-size: 9pt;

note.p: It is not clear to what aberrations M refers. It is also unclear from the layout of the MS whether this comment applies to the entries for Senecio or Cassinia or both (both Asteraceae); Polygonum and Spiraea are Polygonaceae.

note.p: Tate (1890), p. 140, places this species near H. filaginoides, which is listed for SA in B89.12.03, p. 176, along with all other Heliotropium spp included in Tate (1890), p. 247.
